newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU plans to bar state aid for export credit insurance.
newsitem.headline: EU plans to bar state aid for export credit insurance.

text.p: The European Commission has announced plans to shake up the EU's export credit insurance market by phasing out state subsidies on short-term cover and harmonising standards on medium and long-term cover.

According to a statement from the Commission -- the EU's executive -- in the next 12 months member states will have to stop giving state aid to public or publicly supported short-term export credit insurers if a commercial market exists.

But the Commission said state aid could continue "for a while" in countries which did not have a commercial market for export credit insurance. State reinsurance measures will also be allowed in the interim.

A second statement said the Commission had adopted a draft directive on harmonising European standards for medium- and long-term export credit insurance, which is worth some 25-30 billion European currency units a year.

The proposals aim to introduce more transparency to the industry as well as ensure European standards do not contradict negotiations currently being carried out by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.
